sec.p: none

sec.title: Unions
sec.p: none

tr.td: GenericLogicalSpaceClassValue is a code list used to further classify a GenericLogicalSpace.
GenericLogicalSpaceFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a GenericLogicalSpace.
GenericLogicalSpaceUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a GenericLogicalSpace.
GenericOccupiedSpaceClassValue is a code list used to further classify a GenericOccupiedSpace.
GenericOccupiedSpaceFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a GenericOccupiedSpace.
GenericOccupiedSpaceUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a GenericOccupiedSpace.
GenericThematicSurfaceClassValue is a code list used to further classify a GenericThematicSurface.
GenericThematicSurfaceFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a GenericThematicSurface.
GenericThematicSurfaceUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a GenericThematicSurface.
GenericUnoccupiedSpaceClassValue is a code list used to further classify a GenericUnoccupiedSpace.
GenericUnoccupiedSpaceFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a GenericUnoccupiedSpace.
GenericUnoccupiedSpaceUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a GenericUnoccupiedSpace.

sec.title: Enumerations
sec.p: none

tr.td: The LandUse module supports representation of areas of the earth’s surface dedicated to a specific land use.

A LandUse object is an area of the earth’s surface dedicated to a specific land use or having a specific land cover with or without vegetation, such as sand, rock, mud flats, forest, grasslands, or wetlands.
Indicates the specific type of the LandUse.
Specifies the intended purposes of the LandUse.
Specifies the actual uses of the LandUse.
Augments the LandUse with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: ADEOfLandUse acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a LandUse.

sec.title: Basic Types
sec.p: none

sec.title: Unions
sec.p: none

tr.td: LandUseClassValue is a code list used to further classify a LandUse.
LandUseFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a LandUse.
LandUseUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a LandUse.

sec.title: Enumerations
sec.p: none

tr.td: The PointCloud module supports representation of CityGML features by a collection of points.
A PointCloud is an unordered collection of points that is a sampling of the geometry of a space or space boundary.

inlineOrExternalPointCloud (OCL): inv: (points→notEmpty() and mimeType→isEmpty() and pointFile→isEmpty() and pointFileSrsName→isEmpty()) xor (points→isEmpty() and mimeType→notEmpty() and pointFile→notEmpty())
Relates to the 3D MultiPoint geometry of the PointCloud stored inline with the city model.
Specifies the MIME type of the external point cloud file.
Specifies the URI that points to the external point cloud file.
Indicates the coordinate reference system used by the external point cloud file.
Augments the PointCloud with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: ADEOfPointCloud acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a PointCloud.

sec.title: Basic Types
sec.p: none

sec.title: Unions
sec.p: none

sec.title: Code Lists
sec.p: none

sec.title: Enumerations
sec.p: none

tr.td: The Relief module supports representation of the terrain. CityGML supports terrain representations at different levels of detail, reflecting different accuracies or resolutions. Terrain may be specified as a regular raster or grid, as a TIN, by break lines, and/or by mass points.
An AbstractReliefComponent represents an element of the terrain surface — either a TIN, a raster or grid, mass points or break lines.
Indicates the geometrical extent of the terrain component. The geometrical extent is provided as a 2D Surface geometry.
Indicates the Level of Detail of the terrain component.
Augments AbstractReliefComponent with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A BreaklineRelief represents a terrain component with 3D lines. These lines denote break lines or ridge/valley lines.
Relates to the 3D MultiCurve geometry of the MassPointRelief. This association role is used to represent break lines.
Relates to the 3D MultiCurve geometry of the MassPointRelief. This association role is used to represent ridge or valley lines.
Augments the BreaklineRelief with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A MassPointRelief represents a terrain component as a collection of 3D points.
Relates to the 3D PointCloud of the MassPointRelief.
Relates to the 3D MultiPoint geometry of the MassPointRelief.
Augments the MassPointRelief with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A RasterRelief represents a terrain component as a regular raster or grid.
Relates to the DiscreteGridPointCoverage of the RasterRelief.
Augments the RasterRelief with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A ReliefFeature is a collection of terrain components representing the Earth’s surface, also known as the Digital Terrain Model.
Relates to the terrain components that are part of the ReliefFeature.
Indicates the Level of Detail of the ReliefFeature.
Augments the ReliefFeature with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A TINRelief represents a terrain component as a triangulated irregular network.
Relates to the triangulated surface of the TINRelief.
Augments the TINRelief with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: ADEOfAbstractReliefComponent acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractReliefComponent.
ADEOfBreaklineRelief acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a BreaklineRelief.
ADEOfMassPointRelief acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a MassPointRelief.
ADEOfRasterRelief acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a RasterRelief.
ADEOfReliefFeature acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a ReliefFeature.
ADEOfTINRelief acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a TINRelief.

sec.title: Basic Types
sec.p: none

sec.title: Unions
sec.p: none

sec.title: Code Lists
sec.p: none

sec.title: Enumerations
sec.p: none

tr.td: The Transportation module supports representation of the transportation infrastructure. Transportation features include roads, tracks, waterways, railways, and squares. Transportation features may be represented as a network and/or as a collection of spaces or surface elements embedded in a three-dimensional space.
AbstractTransportationSpace is the abstract superclass of transportation objects such as Roads, Tracks, Railways, Waterways or Squares.
Relates to the markings that are part of the transportation space.
Relates to the traffic spaces that are part of the transportation space.
Relates to the auxiliary traffic spaces that are part of the transportation space.
Relates to the holes that are part of the transportation space.
Indicates the direction of traffic flow relative to the corresponding linear geometry representation.
Provides information on the residency of persons, vehicles, or other moving features in the transportation space.
Augments AbstractTransportationSpace with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: An AuxiliaryTrafficArea is the ground surface of an AuxiliaryTrafficSpace.
Indicates the specific type of the AuxiliaryTrafficArea.
Specifies the intended purposes of the AuxiliaryTrafficArea.
Specifies the actual uses of the AuxiliaryTrafficArea.
Specifies the type of pavement of the AuxiliaryTrafficArea.
Augments the AuxiliaryTrafficArea with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: An AuxiliaryTrafficSpace is a space within the transportation space not intended for traffic purposes.
Relates to the auxiliary traffic areas that bound the AuxiliaryTrafficSpace. This relation is inherited from the Core module.
Indicates the specific type of the AuxiliaryTrafficSpace.
Specifies the intended purposes of the AuxiliaryTrafficSpace.
Specifies the actual uses of the AuxiliaryTrafficSpace.
Defines whether auxiliary traffic spaces are represented by individual ways or by individual lanes, depending on the desired level of spatial and semantic decomposition.
Augments the AuxiliaryTrafficSpace with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A ClearanceSpace represents the actual free space above a TrafficArea within which a mobile object can move without contacting an obstruction.
Indicates the specific type of the ClearanceSpace.
Augments the ClearanceSpace with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Hole is an opening in the surface of a Road, Track or Square such as road damages, manholes or drains. Holes can span multiple transportation objects.
Relates to the surfaces that bound the Hole. This relation is inherited from the Core module.
Indicates the specific type of the Hole.
Augments the Hole with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A HoleSurface is a representation of the ground surface of a hole.
Augments the HoleSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: An Intersection is a transportation space that is a shared segment of multiple Road, Track, Railway, or Waterway objects (e.g. a crossing of two roads or a level crossing of a road and a railway).
Indicates the specific type of the Intersection.
Augments the Intersection with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Marking is a visible pattern on a transportation area relevant to the structuring or restriction of traffic. Examples are road markings and markings related to railway or waterway traffic.
Indicates the specific type of the Marking.
Augments the Marking with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Railway is a transportation space used by wheeled vehicles on rails.
Relates to the intersections that are part of the Railway.
Relates to the sections that are part of the Railway.
Indicates the specific type of the Railway.
Specifies the intended purposes of the Railway.
Specifies the actual uses of the Railway.
Augments the Railway with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Road is a transportation space used by vehicles, bicycles and/or pedestrians.
Relates to the intersections that are part of the Road.
Relates to the sections that are part of the Road.
Indicates the specific type of the Road.
Specifies the intended purposes of the Road.
Specifies the actual uses of the Road.
Augments the Road with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Section is a transportation space that is a segment of a Road, Railway, Track, or Waterway.
Indicates the specific type of the Section.
Augments the Section with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Square is a transportation space for unrestricted movement for vehicles, bicycles and/or pedestrians. This includes plazas as well as large sealed surfaces such as parking lots.
Indicates the specific type of the Square.
Specifies the intended purposes of the Square.
Specifies the actual uses of the Square.
Augments the Square with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Track is a small path mainly used by pedestrians. Tracks can be segmented into Sections and Intersections.
Relates to the sections that are part of the Track.
Relates to the intersections that are part of the Track.
Indicates the specific type of the Track.
Specifies the intended purposes of the Track.
Specifies the actual uses of the Track.
Augments the Track with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A TrafficArea is the ground surface of a TrafficSpace. Traffic areas are the surfaces upon which traffic actually takes place.
Indicates the specific type of the TrafficArea.
Specifies the intended purposes of the TrafficArea.
Specifies the actual uses of the TrafficArea.
Specifies the type of pavement of the TrafficArea.
Augments the TrafficArea with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A TrafficSpace is a space in which traffic takes place. Traffic includes the movement of entities such as trains, vehicles, pedestrians, ships, or other transportation types.
Indicates the successor(s) of the TrafficSpace.
Relates to the clearance spaces that are part of the TrafficSpace.
Indicates the predecessor(s) of the TrafficSpace.
Relates to the traffic areas that bound the TrafficSpace. This relation is inherited from the Core module.
Indicates the specific type of the TrafficSpace.
Specifies the intended purposes of the TrafficSpace.
Specifies the actual uses of the TrafficSpace.
Defines whether traffic spaces are represented by individual ways or by individual lanes, depending on the desired level of spatial and semantic decomposition.
Indicates the direction of traffic flow relative to the corresponding linear geometry representation.
Provides information on the residency of persons, vehicles, or other moving features in the TrafficSpace.
Augments the TrafficSpace with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Waterway is a transportation space used for the movement of vessels upon or within a water body.
Relates to the intersections that are part of the Waterway.
Relates to the sections that are part of the Waterway.
Indicates the specific type of the Waterway.
Specifies the intended purposes of the Waterway.
Specifies the actual uses of the Waterway.
Augments the Waterway with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: ADEOfAbstractTransportationSpace acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractTransportationSpace.
ADEOfAuxiliaryTrafficArea acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to an AuxiliaryTrafficArea.
ADEOfAuxiliaryTrafficSpace acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to an AuxiliaryTrafficSpace.
ADEOfClearanceSpace acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a ClearanceSpace.
ADEOfHole acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Hole.
ADEOfHoleSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a HoleSurface.
ADEOfIntersection acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to an Intersection.
ADEOfMarking acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Marking.
ADEOfRailway acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Railway.
ADEOfRoad acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Road.
ADEOfSection acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Section.
ADEOfSquare acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Square.
ADEOfTrack acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Track.
ADEOfTrafficArea acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a TrafficArea.
ADEOfTrafficSpace acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a TrafficSpace.
ADEOfWaterway acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Waterway.

sec.title: Basic Types
sec.p: none

sec.title: Unions
sec.p: none

tr.td: AuxiliaryTrafficAreaClassValue is a code list used to further classify an AuxiliaryTrafficArea.
AuxiliaryTrafficAreaFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of an AuxiliaryTrafficArea.
AuxiliaryTrafficAreaUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of an AuxiliaryTrafficArea.
AuxiliaryTrafficSpaceClassValue is a code list used to further classify an AuxiliaryTrafficSpace.
AuxiliaryTrafficSpaceFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of an AuxiliaryTrafficSpace.
AuxiliaryTrafficSpaceUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of an AuxiliaryTrafficSpace.
ClearanceSpaceClassValue is a code list used to further classify a ClearanceSpace.
HoleClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Hole.
IntersectionClassValue is a code list used to further classify an Intersection.
MarkingClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Marking.
RailwayClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Railway.
RailwayFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a Railway.
RailwayUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a Railway.
RoadClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Road.
RoadFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a Road.
RoadUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a Road.
SectionClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Section.
SquareClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Square.
SquareFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a Square.
SquareUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a Square.
SurfaceMaterialValue is a code list that enumerates the different surface materials.
TrackClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Track.
TrackFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a Track.
TrackUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a Track.
TrafficAreaClassValue is a code list used to further classify a TrafficArea.
TrafficAreaFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a TrafficArea.
TrafficAreaUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a TrafficArea.
TrafficSpaceClassValue is a code list used to further classify a TrafficSpace.
TrafficSpaceFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a TrafficSpace.
TrafficSpaceUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a TrafficSpace.
WaterwayClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Waterway.
WaterwayFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a Waterway.
WaterwayUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a Waterway.
GranularityValue enumerates the different levels of granularity in which transportation objects are represented.
Indicates that the individual lanes of the transportation object are represented.
Indicates that the individual (carriage)ways of the transportation object are represented.
TrafficDirectionValue enumerates the allowed directions of travel of a mobile object.
Indicates that traffic flows in the direction of the corresponding linear geometry.
Indicates that traffic flows in the opposite direction of the corresponding linear geometry.
Indicates that traffic flows in both directions.

The Vegetation module supports representation of vegetation objects with vegetation-specific thematic classes. CityGML’s vegetation model distinguishes between solitary vegetation objects like trees, and vegetation areas which represent biotopes like forests or other plant communities.
AbstractVegetationObject is the abstract superclass for all kinds of vegetation objects.
Augments AbstractVegetationObject with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A PlantCover represents a space covered by vegetation.
Indicates the specific type of the PlantCover.
Specifies the intended purposes of the PlantCover.
Specifies the actual uses of the PlantCover.
Specifies the average height of the PlantCover.
Specifies the minimum height of the PlantCover.
Specifies the maximum height of the PlantCover.
Augments the PlantCover with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A SolitaryVegetationObject represents individual vegetation objects, e.g. trees or bushes.
Indicates the specific type of the SolitaryVegetationObject.
Specifies the intended purposes of the SolitaryVegetationObject.
Specifies the actual uses of the SolitaryVegetationObject.
Indicates the botanical name of the SolitaryVegetationObject.
Distance between the highest point of the vegetation object and the lowest point of the terrain at the bottom of the object.
Specifies the diameter of the SolitaryCityObject’s trunk.
Specifies the diameter of the SolitaryCityObject’s crown.
Specifies the diameter of the SolitaryCityObject’s root ball.
Specifies the vertical distance between the lowest point of the SolitaryVegetationObject’s root ball and the terrain surface.
Augments the SolitaryVegetationObject with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: ADEOfAbstractVegetationObject acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractVegetationObject.
ADEOfPlantCover acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a PlantCover.
ADEOfSolitaryVegetationObject acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a SolitaryVegetationObject.

sec.title: Basic Types
sec.p: none

sec.title: Unions
sec.p: none

tr.td: PlantCoverClassValue is a code list used to further classify a PlantCover.
PlantCoverFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a PlantCover.
PlantCoverUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a PlantCover.
SolitaryVegetationObjectClassValue is a code list used to further classify a SolitaryVegetationObject.
SolitaryVegetationObjectFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a SolitaryVegetationObject.
SolitaryVegetationObjectUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a SolitaryVegetationObject.
A SpeciesValue is a code list that enumerates the species of a SolitaryVegetationObject.

sec.title: Enumerations
sec.p: none

tr.td: The Versioning module supports representation of multiple versions of CityGML features within a single CityGML model. In addition, also the version transitions and transactions that lead to the different versions can be represented.

Version represents a defined state of a city model consisting of the dedicated versions of all city object instances that belong to the respective city model version. Versions can have names, a description and can be labeled with an arbitrary number of user defined tags.
Relates to all city objects that are part of the city model version.
Allows for adding keywords to the city model version.
Augments the Version with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: VersionTransition describes the change of the state of a city model from one version to another. Version transitions can have names, a description and can be further qualified by a type and a reason.
Relates to the predecessor version of the VersionTransition.
Relates to all transactions that have been applied as part of the VersionTransition.
Relates to the successor version of the VersionTransition.
Specifies why the VersionTransition has been carried out.

Indicates whether the set of city object instances belonging to the successor version of the city model is either explicitly enumerated within the successor version object (attribute clonePredecessor=false), or has to be derived from the modifications of the city model provided as a list of transactions on the city object versions contained in the predecessor version (attribute clonePredecessor=true).
Indicates the specific type of the VersionTransition.
Augments the VersionTransition with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: ADEOfVersion acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Version.
ADEOfVersionTransition acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a VersionTransition.

Transaction represents a modification of the city model by the creation, termination, or replacement of a specific city object. While the creation of a city object also marks its first object version, the termination marks the end of existence of a real world object and, hence, also terminates the final version of a city object. The replacement of a city object means that a specific version of it is replaced by a new version.
Relates to the version of the city object subsequent to the Transaction.
Relates to the version of the city object prior to the Transaction.
Indicates the specific type of the Transaction.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

sec.title: Basic Types
sec.p: none

sec.title: Unions
sec.p: none

sec.title: Code Lists
sec.p: none

tr.td: TransactionTypeValue enumerates the three possible types of transactions: insert, delete, or replace.
Indicates that the feature referenced from the Transaction via the “newFeature” association has been newly created; the association “oldFeature” is empty in this case.
Indicates that the feature referenced from the Transaction via the “oldFeature” association ceases to exist; the association “newFeature” is empty in this case.
Indicates that the feature referenced from the Transaction via the “oldFeature” association has been replaced by the feature referenced via the “newFeature” association.

TransitionTypeValue enumerates the different kinds of version transitions. “planned” and “fork” should be used in cases when from one city model version multiple successor versions are being created. “realized” and “merge” should be used when different city model versions are converging into a common successor version.
Indicates that the successor version of the city model represents a planning state for a possible future of the city.
Indicates that the predecessor version is the chosen one from a number of possible planning versions.
Indicates that the successor version reflects updates on the city model over time (historical timeline). It shall only be used for at most one version transition outgoing from a city model version.
Indicates other reasons to create alternative city model versions, for example, when different parties are updating parts of the city model or to reflect the results of different simulation runs.
Indicates other reasons to converge multiple versions back into a common city model version.

The WaterBody module supports representation of the thematic aspects and 3D geometry of rivers, canals, lakes, and basins. It does, however, not inherit any hydrological or other dynamic aspects of fluid flow.
AbstractWaterBoundarySurface is the abstract superclass for all kinds of thematic surfaces bounding a water body.
Augments AbstractWaterBoundarySurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A WaterBody represents significant and permanent or semi-permanent accumulations of surface water, usually covering a part of the Earth.
Indicates the specific type of the WaterBody.
Specifies the intended purposes of the WaterBody.
Specifies the actual uses of the WaterBody.
Augments the WaterBody with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A WaterGroundSurface represents the exterior boundary surface of the submerged bottom of a water body.
Augments the WaterGroundSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A WaterSurface represents the upper exterior interface between a water body and the atmosphere.
Specifies the level of the WaterSurface.
Augments the WaterSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: ADEOfAbstractWaterBoundarySurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractWaterBoundarySurface.
ADEOfWaterBody acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a WaterBody.
ADEOfWaterGroundSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a WaterGroundSurface.
ADEOfWaterSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a WaterSurface.

sec.title: Basic Types
sec.p: none

sec.title: Unions
sec.p: none

tr.td: WaterBodyClassValue is a code list used to further classify a WaterBody.
WaterBodyFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a WaterBody.
WaterBodyUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a WaterBody.
WaterLevelValue is a code list that enumerates the different levels of a water surface.

sec.title: Enumerations
sec.p: none

tr.td: The Construction module supports representation of key elements of different types of constructions. These key elements include construction surfaces (e.g floor and ceiling), windows and doors, constructive elements (e.g. beams and slabs), installations, and furniture.

AbstractConstruction is the abstract superclass for objects that are manufactured by humans from construction materials, are connected to earth, and are intended to be permanent. A connection with the ground also exists when the construction rests by its own weight on the ground or is moveable limited on stationary rails or if the construction is intended to be used mainly stationary.
Relates to the surfaces that bound the construction. This relation is inherited from the Core module.
Indicates the life-cycle status of the construction. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates the date at which the construction was completed.
Indicates the date at which the construction was demolished.
Describes specific events in the life-time of the construction.
Specifies qualified elevations of the construction in relation to a well-defined surface which is commonly taken as origin (e.g. geoid or water level). [cf. INSPIRE]
Specifies qualified heights of the construction above ground or below ground. [cf. INSPIRE]
Provides qualified information on the residency of persons, animals, or other moveable objects in the construction.
Augments AbstractConstruction with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: AbstractConstructionSurface is the abstract superclass for different kinds of surfaces that bound a construction.
Relates to the surfaces that seal the openings of the construction surface.
Augments AbstractConstructionSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: AbstractConstructiveElement is the abstract superclass for the representation of volumetric elements of a construction. Examples are walls, beams, slabs.
Relates to the surfaces that bound the constructive element. This relation is inherited from the Core module.
Relates to the elements that fill the opening of the constructive element.

Indicates whether the constructive element is essential from a structural point of view. A structural element cannot be omitted without collapsing of the construction. Examples are pylons and anchorages of bridges.
Augments AbstractConstructiveElement with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: AbstractFillingElement is the abstract superclass for different kinds of elements that fill the openings of a construction.
Augments AbstractFillingElement with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: AbstractFillingSurface is the abstract superclass for different kinds of surfaces that seal openings filled by filling elements.
Augments AbstractFillingSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: AbstractFurniture is the abstract superclass for the representation of furniture objects of a construction.
Augments AbstractFurniture with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: AbstractInstallation is the abstract superclass for the representation of installation objects of a construction.
Relates to the surfaces that bound the installation. This relation is inherited from the Core module.
Indicates whether the installation is located inside and/or outside of the construction.
Augments AbstractInstallation with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A CeilingSurface is a surface that represents the interior ceiling of a construction. An example is the ceiling of a room.
Augments the CeilingSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Door is a construction for closing an opening intended primarily for access or egress or both. [cf. ISO 6707-1]
Relates to the addresses that are assigned to the Door.
Relates to the door surfaces that bound the Door. This relation is inherited from the Core module.
Indicates the specific type of the Door.
Specifies the intended purposes of the Door.
Specifies the actual uses of the Door.
Augments the Door with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A DoorSurface is either a boundary surface of a Door feature or a surface that seals an opening filled by a door.
Relates to the addresses that are assigned to the DoorSurface.
Augments the DoorSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A FloorSurface is surface that represents the interior floor of a construction. An example is the floor of a room.
Augments the FloorSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A GroundSurface is a surface that represents the ground plate of a construction. The polygon defining the ground plate is congruent with the footprint of the construction.
Augments the GroundSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: An InteriorWallSurface is a surface that is visible from inside a construction. An example is the wall of a room.
Augments the InteriorWallSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: An OtherConstruction is a construction that is not covered by any of the other subclasses of AbstractConstruction.
Indicates the specific type of the OtherConstruction.
Specifies the intended purposes of the OtherConstruction.
Specifies the actual uses of the OtherConstruction.
Augments the OtherConstruction with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: An OuterCeilingSurface is a surface that belongs to the outer building shell with the orientation pointing downwards. An example is the ceiling of a loggia.
Augments the OuterCeilingSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: An OuterFloorSurface is a surface that belongs to the outer construction shell with the orientation pointing upwards. An example is the floor of a loggia.
Augments the OuterFloorSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A RoofSurface is a surface that delimits major roof parts of a construction.
Augments the RoofSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A WallSurface is a surface that is part of the building facade visible from the outside.
Augments the WallSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Window is a construction for closing an opening in a wall or roof, primarily intended to admit light and/or provide ventilation. [cf. ISO 6707-1]
Relates to the window surfaces that bound the Window. This relation is inherited from the Core module.
Indicates the specific type of the Window.
Specifies the intended purposes of the Window.
Specifies the actual uses of the Window.
Augments the Window with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A WindowSurface is either a boundary surface of a Window feature or a surface that seals an opening filled by a window.
Augments the WindowSurface with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: ADEOfAbstractConstruction acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractConstruction.
ADEOfAbstractConstructionSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractConstructionSurface.
ADEOfAbstractConstructiveElement acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractConstructiveElement.
ADEOfAbstractFillingElement acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractFillingElement.
ADEOfAbstractFillingSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractFillingSurface.
ADEOfAbstractFurniture acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractFurniture.
ADEOfAbstractInstallation acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to AbstractInstallation.
ADEOfCeilingSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a CeilingSurface.
ADEOfDoor acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Door.
ADEOfDoorSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a DoorSurface.
ADEOfFloorSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a FloorSurface.
ADEOfGroundSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a GroundSurface.
ADEOfInteriorWallSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to an InteriorWallSurface.
ADEOfOtherConstruction acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to an OtherConstruction.
ADEOfOuterCeilingSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to an OuterCeilingSurface.
ADEOfOuterFloorSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to an OuterFloorSurface.
ADEOfRoofSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a RoofSurface.
ADEOfWallSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a WallSurface.
ADEOfWindow acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a Window.
ADEOfWindowSurface acts as a hook to define properties within an ADE that are to be added to a WindowSurface.
A ConstructionEvent is a data type used to describe a specific event that is associated with a construction. Examples are the issuing of a building permit or the renovation of a building.
Specifies the date at which the event took or will take place.
Provides additional information on the event.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: Elevation is a data type that includes the elevation value itself and information on how this elevation was measured. [cf. INSPIRE]
Specifies the level from which the elevation was measured. [cf. INSPIRE]
Specifies the value of the elevation. [cf. INSPIRE]

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: Height represents a vertical distance (measured or estimated) between a low reference and a high reference. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates the high point used to calculate the value of the height. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates the low point used to calculate the value of the height. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates the way the height has been captured. [cf. INSPIRE]
Specifies the value of the height above or below ground. [cf. INSPIRE]

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

sec.title: Basic Types
sec.p: none

sec.title: Unions
sec.p: none

tr.td: DoorClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Door.
DoorFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a Door.
DoorUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a Door.
ElevationReferenceValue is a code list that enumerates the different elevation reference levels used to measure construction heights.
EventValue is a code list that enumerates the different events of a construction.
OtherConstructionClassValue is a code list used to further classify an OtherConstruction.
OtherConstructionFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of an OtherConstruction.
OtherConstructionUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of an OtherConstruction.
WindowClassValue is a code list used to further classify a Window.
WindowFunctionValue is a code list that enumerates the different purposes of a Window.
WindowUsageValue is a code list that enumerates the different uses of a Window.
ConditionOfConstructionValue enumerates different conditions of a construction. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates that the construction cannot be used under normal conditions, though its main elements (walls, roof) are still present. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates that the construction has been demolished. There are no more visible remains. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates that the construction is functional. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates that the construction is being designed. Construction works have not yet started. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates that the construction has been partly demolished and some main elements (roof, walls) have been destroyed. There are some visible remains of the construction. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates that the construction is under construction and not yet functional. This applies only to the initial construction works of the construction and not to maintenance work. [cf. INSPIRE]
HeightStatusValue enumerates the different methods used to capture a height. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates that the height has been estimated and not measured. [cf. INSPIRE]
Indicates that the height has been (directly or indirectly) measured. [cf. INSPIRE]
RelationToConstruction is an enumeration used to describe whether an installation is positioned inside and/or outside of a construction.
Indicates that the installation is positioned inside of the construction.
Indicates that the installation is positioned outside of the construction.
Indicates that the installation is positioned inside as well as outside of the construction.
The Bridge module supports representation of thematic and spatial aspects of bridges, bridge parts, bridge installations, and interior bridge structures.
AbstractBridge is an abstract superclass representing the common attributes and associations of the classes Bridge and BridgePart.
Relates the constructive elements to the Bridge or BridgePart.
Relates the installation objects to the Bridge or BridgePart.
Relates the furniture objects to the Bridge or BridgePart.
Relates the rooms to the Bridge or BridgePart.
Relates the addresses to the Bridge or BridgePart.
Indicates the specific type of the Bridge or BridgePart.
Specifies the intended purposes of the Bridge or BridgePart.
Specifies the actual uses of the Bridge or BridgePart.
Indicates whether the Bridge or BridgePart can be moved to allow for watercraft to pass.
Augments AbstractBridge with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A Bridge represents a structure that affords the passage of pedestrians, animals, vehicles, and service(s) above obstacles or between two points at a height above ground. [cf. ISO 6707-1]
Relates the bridge parts to the Bridge.
Augments the Bridge with properties defined in an ADE.

td.p: Note: Unless otherwise specified, all attributes and role names have the stereotype «Property».

tr.td: A BridgeConstructiveElement is an element of a bridge which is essential from a structural point of view. Examples are pylons, anchorages, slabs, beams.
Indicates the specific type of the BridgeConstructiveElement.
Specifies the intended purposes of the BridgeConstructiveElement.

sec.title: Application Domain Extension (ADE)
sec.p: An Application Domain Extension (ADE) is a formal and systematic extension of the CityGML Conceptual Model (CM) for a specific application or domain. The ADE is expressed in the form of a UML conceptual model. The domain data is mapped to a set of additional classes, attributes, and relations. ADEs may use elements from the CityGML CM to derive application-specific subclasses, to inject additional properties, to associate application data with predefined CityGML content, or to define value domains for attributes.

The ADE mechanism allows application-specific information to be aligned with the CityGML CM in a well-structured and systematic way. By this means, CityGML can be extended to meet the information needs of an application while at the same time preserving its concepts and semantic structures. Moreover, and in contrast to generic city objects and attributes, application data can be validated against the formal definition of an ADE to ensure semantic interoperability.

Previous versions of the CityGML Standard defined the ADE mechanism solely at the level of the XML Schema encoding. With CityGML 3.0, ADEs become platform-independent models at a conceptual level that can be mapped to multiple and different target encodings.
ADEs have successfully been implemented in practice and enable a wide range of applications and use cases based on the CityGML Standard. An overview and discussion of existing ADEs is provided in [].

sec.title: General Rules for ADEs
sec.p: An ADE shall be defined as a UML conceptual model in accordance with the General Feature Model and the rules for creating application schemas in UML as specified in 4 and the rules and constraints for using UML to model geographic information as specified in 4. The 6.2 used in the CityGML conceptual model should also be applied to corresponding model elements in an ADE.

Every ADE shall be organized into one or more UML packages having globally unique namespaces and containing all UML model elements defined by the ADE. An ADE may additionally import and use predefined classes from external conceptual UML models such as the CityGML modules or the standardized schemas of the ISO 19100 series of International Standards.

sec.title: Defining New ADE Model Elements
sec.p: Following ISO 19109, the primary view of geospatial information and the core element of application schemas is the feature. ADEs therefore typically extend CityGML by defining new feature types appropriate to the application area together with additional content such as object types, data types, code lists, and enumerations.

Every feature type in an ADE shall be derived either directly or indirectly from the CityGML root feature type Core::AbstractFeature or, depending on its type and characteristics, from a more appropriate subclass thereof. According to the general CityGML space concept, features representing spaces or space boundaries shall be derived either directly or indirectly from Core::AbstractSpace or Core::AbstractSpaceBoundary respectively. UML classes representing top-level feature types shall use the «TopLevelFeatureType» stereotype.
In contrast to feature types, object types and data types are not required to be derived from a predefined CityGML class unless explicitly stated otherwise.

ADE classes may have an unlimited number of attributes and associations in addition to those inherited from their parents. Attributes can be modelled with either simple or complex data types. To ensure semantic interoperability, the predefined types from CityGML or the standardized schemas of the ISO 19100 series of International Standards should be used wherever appropriate. This includes, amongst others, basic types from ISO/TS 19103, geometry and topology objects from ISO 10107, and temporal geometry and topology objects from ISO 19108.

If a predefined type is not available, ADEs can either define their own data types or import data types from external conceptual models. This explicitly includes the possibility of defining new geometry types not offered by ISO 19107. Designers of an ADE should however note that software might not be able to properly identify and consume such geometry types.

A feature type capturing a real-world feature with geometry should be derived either directly or indirectly from Core::AbstractSpace or Core::AbstractSpaceBoundary. By this means, the CityGML predefined spatial properties and the associated LOD concept are inherited and available for the feature type. If, however, these superclasses are either inappropriate or lack a spatial property required to represent the feature, an ADE may define new and additional spatial properties. If such a spatial property should belong to one of the predefined LODs, then the property name shall start with the prefix “lodX”, where X is to be replaced by an integer value between 0 and 3 indicating the target LOD. This enables software to derive the LOD of the geometry.

Constraints on model elements should be expressed using a formal language such as the Object Constraint Language (OCL). The ADE specifies the manner of application of constraints. However, following the CityGML conceptual model, constraints should at least be expressed on ADE subclasses of Core::AbstractSpace to limit the types of space boundaries (i.e., instances of Core::AbstractSpaceBoundary) that may be used to model the boundary of a space object.
Illustrative examples for ADEs can be found in the .

sec.title: Augmenting CityGML Feature Types with Additional ADE Properties
sec.p: If a predefined CityGML feature type lacks one or more properties required for a specific application, a feasible solution in CityGML 2.0 was to derive a new ADE feature type as subclass of the CityGML class and to add the properties to this subclass. While conceptually clean, this approach also faces drawbacks. If multiple ADEs require additional properties for the same CityGML feature type, this will lead to many subclasses of this feature type in different ADE namespaces. Information about the same real-world feature might therefore be spread over various instances of the different feature classes in an encoding making it difficult for software to consume the feature data.

For this reason, CityGML 3.0 provides a way to augment the predefined CityGML feature types with additional properties from the ADE domain without the need for subclassing. Each CityGML feature type has an extension attribute of name “adeOfFeatureTypeName” and type “ADEOfFeatureTypeName”, where FeatureTypeName is replaced by the class name in which the attribute is defined. For example, the Building::Building class offers the attribute adeOfBuilding of type Building::ADEOfBuilding. Each of these extension attributes can occur zero to unlimited times, and the attribute types are defined as abstract and empty data types.

If an ADE augments a specific CityGML feature type with additional ADE properties, the ADE shall create a subclass of the corresponding abstract data type associated with the feature class. This subclass shall also be defined as data type using the stereotype «DataType». The additional application-specific attributes and associations are then modelled as properties of the ADE subclass. This may include, amongst others, attributes with simple or complex data type, spatial properties or associations to other object and feature types from the ADE or external models such as CityGML.

The predefined “ADEOfFeatureTypeName” data types are called “hooks” because they are used as the head of a hierarchy of ADE subclasses attaching application-specific properties. When subclassing the “hook” of a specific CityGML feature type in an ADE, the properties defined in the subclass can be used for that feature type as well as for all directly or indirectly derived feature types, including feature types defined in the same or another ADE.

Multiple distinct ADEs can use the “hook” mechanism to define additional ADE properties for the same CityGML feature type. Since the “adeOfFeatureTypeName” attribute may occur multiple times, the various ADE properties can be exchanged as part of the same CityGML feature instance in an encoding. Software can therefore easily consume the default CityGML feature data plus the additional properties from the different ADEs.
Content from unknown or unsupported ADEs may be ignored by an application or service consuming an encoded CityGML model.

Designers of an ADE should favor using this “hook” mechanism over subclassing a CityGML feature type when possible. If an ADE must enable other ADEs to augment its own feature types (so-called ADE of an ADE), then it shall implement “hooks” for its feature types following the same schema and naming concept as in the CityGML conceptual model.
The UML fragment in 11.3 shows an example for using the “hook” mechanism. For more details on this and other example ADEs, please see the for an example ADE.

caption.title: The CityGML feature type Building is augmented with additional ADE properties by defining the data type EnergyProperties as a subclass of the ADE data type ADEOfBuilding.

sec.title: Encoding of ADEs
sec.p: This document only addresses the conceptual modelling of ADEs. Rules and constraints for mapping a conceptual ADE model to a target encoding are expected to be defined in a corresponding CityGML Encoding Standard. If supported, an ADE may provide additional mapping rules and constraints in conformance with a corresponding CityGML Encoding Standard.

sec.title: Requirements and Recommendations
sec.p: The following requirements and recommendations specify how ADEs shall be used as an extension capability to the CityGML Conceptual Model.

sec.title: UML
sec.p: Any extension to the CityGML Conceptual Model should be a faithful continuation of the styles and techniques used in that model. The following Requirements and Recommendations define a “faithful continuation”.

tr.td: An ADE SHALL be defined as conceptual model in UML in accordance with the conceptual modelling framework of the ISO 19100 series of International Standards
The UML model SHALL adhere to the General Feature Model as specified in ISO 19109.
The UML model SHALL adhere to rules and constraints for application schemas as specified in ISO/TS 19103.
Every ADE SHALL be organized into one or more UML packages having globally unique namespaces and containing all UML model elements defined by the ADE.

sec.p: Unresolved directive in sections/clause_10_application_domain_extension.adoc — include::recommendations/ADE/REC_ADE_UML.adoc[]

sec.title: Classes
sec.p: The following Requirements and Recommendations define how CityGML classes should be extended by an ADE.

tr.td: ADEs typically extend CityGML by defining new Feature Types together with additional content such as Object Types, Data Types, Code Lists, and Enumerations.
Every Feature Type in an ADE SHALL be derived either directly or indirectly from the CityGML root Feature Type core:AbstractFeature or a subclass thereof.
UML classes representing Top-Level Feature Types SHALL use the «TopLevelFeatureType» stereotype.
Features representing spaces or space boundaries SHALL be derived either directly or indirectly from core:AbstractSpace or core:AbstractSpaceBoundary respectively.

An ADE may define new and additional spatial properties. If such a spatial property should belong to a predefined LOD, then the property name SHALL start with the prefix “lodX”, where X is an integer value indicating the target LOD.

sec.p: Unresolved directive in sections/clause_10_application_domain_extension.adoc — include::recommendations/ADE/REC_ADE_Elements.adoc[]

sec.title: Properties
sec.p: The following Requirements define how to use the CityGML extension properties to add attributes to an existing CityGML Feature Type.

tr.td: Every Feature Type includes an extension property (hook) of type “ADEOf<FeatureTypeName>” where <FeatureTypeName> is the name of that Feature Type. To add an extension property to a Feature Type:
The ADE SHALL create a subclass of the abstract data type associated with the hook.
This subclass SHALL be defined as a data type using the stereotype «DataType».
Application-specific attributes and associations SHALL be modeled as properties of the ADE subclass.

sec.label: A.1
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: CityGML 3.0 is a Conceptual Model. Since it is agnostic to implementing technologies, an Executable Test Script is not feasible. It becomes the responsibility of the Implementation Specifications to provide evidence of conformance. This evidence should be provided as an annex to the Implementation Specification document.
The test method specified in this ATS is manual inspection. Automated methods may be used where they exist.

app.label: Annex C
app.title: Glossary
app.p:
conformance test class
The set of conformance test modules that must be applied to receive a single certificate of conformance [OGC 08-131r3, definition 4.4]

feature
An abstraction of real world phenomena [ISO 19101-1:2014, definition 4.1.11]

feature attribute
A characteristic of a feature [ISO 19101-1:2014, definition 4.1.12]

feature type
A class of features having common characteristics [ISO 19156:2011, definition 4.7]

measurement
A set of operations having the object of determining the value of a quantity [ISO 19101-2:2018, definition 3.21] / [VIM:1993, 2.1]

model
An abstraction of some aspects of reality [ISO 19109:2015, definition 4.15]

observation
The act of measuring or otherwise determining the value of a property [ISO 19156:2011, definition 4.11]

observation procedure
A method, algorithm or instrument, or system of these, which may be used in making an observation [ISO 19156:2011, 4.12]

observation result
An estimate of the value of a property determined through a known observation procedure [ISO 19156:2011, 4.14]

property
A facet or attribute of an object referenced by a name. [ISO 19143:2010, definition 4.21]

requirements class
The aggregate of all requirement modules that must all be satisfied to satisfy a conformance test class [OGC 08-131r3, definition 4.19]

schema
The formal description of a model [ISO 19101-1:2014, definition 4.1.34]

sensor
A type of observation procedure that provides the estimated value of an observed property at its output [OGC 08-094r1, definition 4.5]

Standardization Target
An entity to which some requirements of a standard apply [OGC 08-131r3, definition 4.23]

timeseries
A sequence of data values which are ordered in time [OGC 15-043r3]

universe of discourse
View of the real or hypothetical world that includes everything of interest [ISO 19101-1:2014, definition 4.1.38]

version
Particular variation of a spatial object [INSPIRE Glossary]

sec.label: C.1
sec.title: ISO Concepts
sec.p: The following concepts from the ISO TC211 Harmonized UML model are referenced by the CityGML Conceptual UML model but do not play a major role in its’ definition. They are provided here to support a more complete understanding of the model.

Area
The measure of the physical extent of any topologically 2-D geometric object. Usually measured in “square” units of length. [4]

Boolean
Boolean is the mathematical datatype associated with two-valued logic [4]

CC_CoordinateOperation
A mathematical operation on coordinates that transforms or converts coordinates to another coordinate reference system. [4]

Character
A symbol from a standard character-set. [4]

CharacterString
Characterstring is a family of datatypes which represent strings of symbols from standard character-sets. [4]

CRS
Coordinate reference system which is usually single but may be compound. [4]

CV_DiscreteCoverage
A subclass of CV_Coverage that returns a single record of values for any direct position within a single geometric object in its spatiotemporal domain. [4]

CV_DomainObject
An element of the domain of the CV_Coverage. It is an aggregation of objects that may include any combination of GM_Objects (ISO 19107:2003), TM_GeometricPrimitives (ISO 10108), or spatial or temporal objects defined in other standards, such as the CV_GridPoint defined in this International Standard. [4]

CV_GridPointValuePair
A subtype of CV_GeometryValuePair that has a GM_GridPoint as the value of its geometry attribute. [4]

CV_GridValuesMatrix
The geometry represented by the various offset vectors is in the image plane of the grid. [4]

CV_ReferenceableGrid
A subclass of CV_Coverage that relates the grid coordinates to an external coordinate reference system. [4]

Date
Date gives values for year, month and day. Representation of Date is specified in ISO 8601. Principles for date and time are further discussed in ISO 19108. [4]

DateTime
A DateTime is a combination of a date and a time types. Representation of DateTime is specified in ISO 8601. Principles for date and time are further discussed in ISO 19108. [4]

Distance
Used as a type for returning distances and possibly lengths. [4]

Engineering CRS
A contextually local coordinate reference system which can be divided into two broad categories:

list-item.label: a)
list-item.p: earth-fixed systems applied to engineering activities on or near the surface of the earth;

list-item.label: b)
list-item.p: CRSs on moving platforms such as road vehicles, vessels, aircraft or spacecraft. [4]

sec.p:
Generic Name
Generic Name is the abstract class for all names in a NameSpace. Each instance of a GenericName is either a LocalName or a ScopedName. [4]

Geometry
Geometry is the root class of the geometric object taxonomy and supports interfaces common to all geographically referenced geometric objects. [4]

GM_CompositePoint
A GM_Complex containing one and only one GM_Point. [4]

GM_CompositeSolid
A set of geometric solids adjoining one another along common boundary geometric surfaces [4]

GM_GenericSurface
GM_Surface and GM_SurfacePatch both represent sections of surface geometry, and therefore share a number of operation signatures. These are defined in the interface class GM_GenericSurface. [4]

GM_LineString
Consists of sequence of line segments, each having a parameterization like the one for GM_LineSegment [4]

GM_MultiPrimitive
The root class for all primitive aggregates. The association role “element” shall be the set of GM_Primitives contained in this GM_MultiPrimitive. The attribute declaration here specializes the one at GM_Aggregate to include only GM_Primitives in this type of aggregate. [4]

GM_OrientableSurface
A surface and an orientation inherited from GM_OrientablePrimitive. If the orientation is “+”, then the GM_OrientableSurface is a GM_Surface. If the orientation is “-”, then the GM_OrientableSurface is a reference to a GM_Surface with an upNormal that reverses the direction for this GM_OrientableSurface, the sense of “the top of the surface”. [4]

GM_PolyhedralSurface
A GM_Surface composed of polygon surfaces (GM_Polygon) connected along their common boundary curves. [4]

GM_Position
A union type consisting of either a DirectPosition or of a reference to a GM_Point from which a DirectPosition shall be obtained. [4]

GM_Primitive
The abstract root class of the geometric primitives. Its main purpose is to define the basic “boundary” operation that ties the primitives in each dimension together. [4]

Integer
An exact integer value, with no fractional part. [4]

Internet of Things
The network of physical objects—“things”—that are embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for the purpose of connecting and exchanging data with other devices and systems over the Internet. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_of_things

IO_IdentifiedObjectBase
Supplementary identification and remarks information for a CRS or CRS-related object. [4]

Length
The measure of distance as an integral, i.e. the limit of an infinite sum of distances between points on a curve. [4]

Measure
The result from performing the act or process of ascertaining the extent, dimensions, or quantity of some entity. [4]

Number
The base type for all number data, giving the basic algebraic operations. [4]

Point
GM_Point is the basic data type for a geometric object consisting of one and only one point. [4]

Real
The common binary Real finite implementation using base 2. [4]

RS_ReferenceSystem
Description of a spatial and temporal reference system used by a dataset. [4]

Scoped Name
ScopedName is a composite of a LocalName for locating another NameSpace and a GenericName valid in that NameSpace. ScopedName contains a LocalName as head and a GenericName, which might be a LocalName or a ScopedName, as tail. [4]

Solid
GM_Solid, a subclass of GM_Primitive, is the basis for 3-dimensional geometry. The extent of a solid is defined by the boundary surfaces. [4]

Time
Time is the designation of an instant on a selected time scale, astronomical or atomic. It is used in the sense of time of day. [4]

TM_Duration
A data type to be used for describing length or distance in the temporal dimension. [4]

TM_TemporalPosition
The position of a TM_Instant relative to a TM_ReferenceSystem. [4]

Unit of Measure
Any of the systems devised to measure some physical quantity such distance or area or a system devised to measure such things as the passage of time. [4]

URI
Uniform Resource Identifier (URI), is a compact string of characters used to identify or name a resource [4]

Volume
Volume is the measure of the physical space of any 3-D geometric object. [4]
